case_name: Dr. Yash Pal Sahi v. Delhi Administration

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 157 of 1962 filed by special leave from judgment and order dated February 9, 1962 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Criminal Revision Application No. 281-D of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 157 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 9, 1962, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Criminal

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 29, 1963 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: November 29, 1963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-The appellant, Dr. Yash Pal Sahi, and his wife Dr. Susheela Sahi, are the proprietors, of a homoeopathic hospital

facts.text: Appellant Dr. Yash Pal Sahi and his wife Dr. Susheela Sahi are proprietors of a homoeopathic hospital at Jangpura in New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Dr. Yash Pal Sahi, and his wife Dr. Susheela Sahi, are the proprietors, of a homoeopathic hospital at Jangpura in New Delhi. They also run a journal called the Homoeopathic Doctor.

facts.text: Appellant and wife run a journal called the Homoeopathic Doctor.

anchor.surface_text: They also run a journal called the Homoeopathic Doctor. It appears that on May 15, 1958 Misri Singh wrote to the appellant that the medicines manufactured by him were proving effective, and he therefore

facts.text: On May 15, 1958 Misri Singh wrote to the appellant requesting Homoeopathic Doctor magazine from January 15, 1958 and list of medicines, promising to pay by V.P.P.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on May 15, 1958 Misri Singh wrote to the appellant that the medicines manufactured by him were proving effective, and he therefore requested the appellant to send him his magazine Homoeopathic Doctor from January 15, 1958 up to the date of the letter. In this letter, Misri Singh also requested the doctor to send him a list of medicines that might have been printed by him and he promised to pay the requisite prices and suggested that the same should be sent by V.P.P.

facts.text: Packet containing Exhibits P-1 to P-6 (copies of Homoeopathic Doctor) and Ex. P-7 (list of medicines) sent to Misri Singh on May 24, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, a packet companytaining Exhibits P-1 to P-6 which are companyies of the Homoeopathic Doctor and Ex. P-7, which is a list of medicines was sent to Misri Singh on May, 24, 1958. Misri Singh had written to the appellant under the instructions of Mr Seth, who is an officer in the Delhi Administration.

facts.text: Misri Singh wrote to appellant under instructions of Mr. Seth, officer in Delhi Administration.

anchor.surface_text: Misri Singh had written to the appellant under the instructions of Mr Seth, who is an officer in the Delhi Administration. That is why when the packet was received by Misri Singh it was opened by him in the presence of Mr. Seth and other witnesses and the packet was found to companytain Exs. P-1 to P-7.

facts.text: Packet received by Misri Singh opened in presence of Mr. Seth and other witnesses, found to contain Exs. P-1 to P-7.

anchor.surface_text: That is why when the packet was received by Misri Singh it was opened by him in the presence of Mr. Seth and other witnesses and the packet was found to companytain Exs. P-1 to P-7. The prosecution alleged that by sending this packet to Misri Singh both the appellant and his wife had companymitted an offence under s. 3 read with s. 7 of the Drugs and Magic Remedies  Objectionable Advertisement  Act of 1954.

facts.text: Prosecution alleged appellant and wife committed offence under s. 3 read with s. 7 of Drugs and Magic Remedies (Objectionable Advertisement) Act 1954 by sending the packet.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution alleged that by sending this packet to Misri Singh both the appellant and his wife had companymitted an offence under s. 3 read with s. 7 of the Drugs and Magic Remedies  Objectionable Advertisement  Act of 1954. Later, the companyplaint against Dr. Susheela Sahi was withdrawn and the case proceeded only against the appellant.

facts.text: Complaint against Dr. Susheela Sahi withdrawn, case proceeded only against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Later, the companyplaint against Dr. Susheela Sahi was withdrawn and the case proceeded only against the appellant. At the trial, evidence was given by Mr. Seth, Misri Singh and Dr. Anant Parkash, with whom Misri Singh works as a clerk.

facts.text: At trial, evidence given by Mr. Seth, Misri Singh, and Dr. Anant Parkash (Misri Singh's employer).

anchor.surface_text: At the trial, evidence was given by Mr. Seth, Misri Singh and Dr. Anant Parkash, with whom Misri Singh works as a clerk. The appellant was questioned by the learned Magistrate, who tried the case, and he admitted that Exs. P-1 to P-7 had been sent to Misri Singh.

facts.text: Appellant admitted to learned Magistrate that Exs. P-1 to P-7 sent to Misri Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was questioned by the learned Magistrate, who tried the case, and he admitted that Exs. P-1 to P-7 had been sent to Misri Singh. On these facts, the learned Magistrate held that the appellant was guilty of the offence charged and sentenced him to pay a fine of Rs. 1,000.

facts.text: Learned Magistrate held appellant guilty and sentenced to fine of Rs. 1,000.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts, the learned Magistrate held that the appellant was guilty of the offence charged and sentenced him to pay a fine of Rs. 1,000. The appellant challenged the companyrectness of this order by an appeal before the Additional Sessions Judge at New Delhi.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Additional Sessions Judge at New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the companyrectness of this order by an appeal before the Supreme Additional Sessions Judge at New Delhi. The learned additional Sessions Judge companysidered the evidence, and companyfirmed the findings recorded by the trial Magistrate.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge confirmed conviction, reduced sentence to fine of Rs. 500.

anchor.surface_text: The learned additional Sessions Judge companysidered the evidence, and companyfirmed the findings recorded by the trial Magistrate. In the result, the order of companyviction passed against the appellant was affirmed but in regard to the sentence the learned Additional Sessions Judge took the view that a fine of Rs. 500 would meet the ends of justice.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge found parcel containing Exs. P-1 to P-7 sent by appellant to Misri Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The findings made by the appellate Court show that the -parcel companytaining Exs. P-1 to P-7 had been sent by the appellant to Misri Singh. Exhibits P-1 to P-6 which -are the numbers of the publication Homoeopathic Doctor did number companye within the mischief of the Act,

facts.text: Exhibits P-1 to P-6 are issues of Homoeopathic Doctor and come within the mischief of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Exhibits P-1 to P-6 which -are the numbers of the publication Homoeopathic Doctor did number companye within the mischief of the Act, but Ex. P-7, which is Fehrist-i- Mujarabat did companye within the mischief of the Act. It is a list of medicines, and it purports to advertise the said medicines by describing their effect, and prices of the medicines are also printed.

facts.text: Ex. P-7 is Fehrist-i-Mujarabat, a list of medicines purporting to advertise them by describing effects and printing prices, comes within mischief of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: but Ex. P-7, which is Fehrist-i- Mujarabat did companye within the mischief of the Act. It is a list of medicines, and it purports to advertise the said medicines by describing their effect, and prices of the medicines are also printed. Inasmuch as it was found by the learned Additional Sessions Judge that the appellant had sent Ex. P-7 to Misri Singh, his companyviction was held to be justified under s. 3 read with s. 7 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant filed revisional application before High Court, dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then took this matter before the High Court by a revisional application It was urged before the High Court on his behalf that in deciding the question as to whether the appellant was guilty under s. 3 read with s. 7 the effect of the provisions companytained in s. 14 1  c  had number been properly appreciated.

facts.text: Misri Singh works as a clerk with Dr. Anant Parkash.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial, evidence was given by Mr. Seth, Misri Singh and Dr. Anant Parkash, with whom Misri Singh works as a clerk.

facts.text: Misri Singh is not a registered medical practitioner.

anchor.surface_text: It has been proved as a fact that Mr. Misri Singh is number a registered medical practitioner, and so, the question arises whether the appellant can claim that his case falls under s. 14 1  c  at all.

facts.text: Ex. P-7 bears printed in indelible ink the statement that it was meant for the use of registered medical practitioners alone.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the list sent by the appellant to Misri Singh does bear printed in indelible ink the statement that it was meant for the use of registered medical practitioners alone.

facts.text: High Court dismissed revisional application of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was number impressed by this argument. Accordingly, the revisional application filed by the appellant was dismissed. It is against this order that the appellant has companye to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Exhibits P-7 contains medicines which fall within scope of ss. 3(c) and (d).

anchor.surface_text: It has been found and cannot be number disputed that the list of advertisements  Ex. P-7  companytains medicines which fall within the scope of ss. 3 c  and  d .

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge reduced fine to Rs. 500.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the sentence, the learned Additional Sessions Judge has reduced the sentence of Rs. 1,000 fine imposed on the appellant by the learned trial Magistrate to Rs. 500 and that we think is a fair order to make.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 9, 1962, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Criminal Revision

The prosecution alleged that by sending this packet to Misri Singh both the appellant and his wife had committed an offence under s. 3 read with s. 7 of the Drugs and Magic Remedies  Objectionable Advertisement  Act of 1954. Later, the complaint against Dr. Susheela Sahi was withdrawn and the case proceeded only against the appellant.

holdings.text: The definition under s.2(d) is wide enough to include sending the advertisement within India as 'taking part in the publication'.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore it seems to us that the definition prescribed by s.  2d is wide enough to take in the printing of the advertisement and the sending of it to any part of India. That takes us to s. 3 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inclusive definition covers printing and sending outside India; analogously extends to sending within India.

holdings.text: Ex. P-7 contains medicines which fall within the scope of ss. 3(c) and 3(d).

anchor.surface_text: It has been found and cannot be disputed that the list of advertisements  Ex. P-7  contains medicines which fall within the scope of ss. 3 c  and  d .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed finding based on content of Ex. P-7 describing effects for prohibited purposes.

holdings.text: A single contravention of the Act is sufficient to attract penalty under s.7.

anchor.surface_text: This section shows that before a person is penalised it is not necessary to show that the contravention brought home to him is in the nature of a habitual contravention. A single contravention proved against a person would make him guilty under s. 7.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of s.7 distinguishes first and subsequent convictions, allowing punishment for single offence.

holdings.text: s.3 is subject to exceptions in s.14, but the appellant's case does not fall under s.14(1)(c) as Misri Singh is not a registered medical practitioner.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Goyal contends that in considering the question as to whether the appellant is guilty under s. 3 and s. 7 read together it is necessary to consider whether this case falls under s. 14 or not. He argues that s. 3 begins with the clause Subject to the provisions of this Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution proved recipient not registered; no evidence accused satisfied exception conditions.

holdings.text: Once prosecution proves recipient is not a registered medical practitioner, burden shifts to accused to prove case falls under s.14(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: It has been proved as a fact that Mr. Misri Singh is not a registered medical practitioner, and so, the question arises whether the appellant can claim that his case falls under s. 14 1  c  at all. It is true that in order to bring home to the appellant the offence charged the prosecution may have to show that the person to whom the list was sent was not a registered medical practitioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution establishes basic offence; accused must prove qualifying exception.

holdings.text: Mere printing of the legend under r.6 is insufficient; advertisement must be sent confidentially in prescribed manner to a registered medical practitioner.

anchor.surface_text: We are not prepared to accept this argument. Rule 6 prescribes some conditions which- have to be complied with by a person who sends lists of medicines to Which the Act applies so as to bring his case within s. 14  1  c  One requirement is that the list should have printed in indelible ink the statement to which we have just referred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.6 and s.14(1)(c) require all conditions including proper recipient; partial compliance inadequate.

holdings.text: The offence under s.3 read with s.7 has been duly proved against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the High Court was right in holding that the offence charged against the appellant has been duly proved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show sending of prohibited advertisement to non-qualified person without exception applying; lower courts correct.

holdings.text: The sentence of fine of Rs.500 is fair and meets the ends of justice.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the sentence, the learned Additional Sessions Judge has reduced the sentence of Rs. 1,000 fine imposed on the appellant by the learned trial Magistrate to Rs. 500 and that we think is a fair order to make.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reduction by lower court appropriate for first offence.
